repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

body:
Problem:
We don't have flatten / flatMap for `vim.iter` https://github.com/neovim/neovim/issues/26454

Solution: Implement flat, with a default depth to 1. This is similar to the way `Array.prototype.flat` works in [ECMAScript](https://tc39.es/ecma262/multipage/indexed-collections.html#sec-array.prototype.flat). It only works for list-like iterators

comment_data.body: I couldn't find a better way to do this than making a copy. I tried for some in-place magic, but it seemed to be going nowhere. This is basically what the ES spec does as well ü§∑‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏è

@@ -179,6 +193,45 @@ function ListIter.filter(self, f)
   return self
 end
 
+--- Flattens an |list-iterator| pipeline, un-nesting nested values
+---
+--- Example:
+---
+--- ```lua
+--- vim.iter({1, {2}, {{3}}}):flat():totable()
+--- ```
+--- (returns {1, 2, {3}})

+end
+
+---@private
+function ListIter.flat(self, depth)
+  depth = depth or 1
+  local inc = self._head < self._tail and 1 or -1
+  local target = {}

+function ListIter.flat(self, depth)
+  depth = depth or 1

+  local n = 1

comment_data.body:
By choosing that default, I was trying to mimic the behavior of the [ECMAScript method](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Global_Objects/Array/flat) `Arrays.prototype.flat`, which was mentioned in the original issue thread. That is probably the implementation with which people are most familiar. 

Fully flattening by default is definitely another option here. ES uses a depth of infinity to fully flatten a table, but comparisons with infinity, which could be less intuitive to users. in Lua: 

```lua
-- flatten a table to infinite depth (math.huge = inf)
print(vim.inspect(vim.iter.flatten({1, {2}, {{3}}, {{{{4}}}}}, math.huge)))

```

Consistent is also better. `flat()` feels like a very bizarre function name, it is neither a noun nor a verb. The rest of the API in vim.iter() (and our API in general) uses verbs for function names to indicate it ‚Äúdoes something‚Äù.

`flatten` is also, as far as I know, much more common in other languages. In fact, aside from the one JavaScript implementation you linked to I‚Äôve never seen such a function called `flat` https://rosettacode.org/wiki/Flatten_a_list

https://v2.ocaml.org/api/List.html#VALflatten

https://doc.rust-lang.org/std/iter/trait.Iterator.html#method.flatten

https://www.erlang.org/doc/man/lists#flatten-1

comment_data.body:
Seems strange that it oblietrates nested maps. Was this already discussed? How are maps/dicts treated in other flatten() implementations (e.g. JS, erlang)?

In JS a nested "map" is an object. And in Lua, a table has a similar role: it's a basic "object" whose keys are its properties/members. So I don't see why it should be hollowed out by flatten(). 

```suggestion
    <(returns `{1, {a = 2}, 3}` )
```

comment_data.body:
Typing-wise `@param depth? number`, `@param depth number?`, `@param depth number|nil`, are all equivalent because Lua does not distinguish between `.flatten(nil)` and `.flatten()` , but to me `depth?` more sounds like an *optional* parameter. In the neovim codebase we mix these interchangeably and I know `@param depth number|nil` style is often used, so I don't have a strong preference here.

https://luals.github.io/wiki/annotations/#param
> Putting a question mark (?) after the parameter name will mark it as optional, meaning nil is an accepted type

comment_data.body:
Ditch the `(internal)` marker, make the arguments non-optional, we can provide initial values in the call site in `Iter:flatten()`.

I'm also fine naming this local function just `flatten`.

```suggestion
--- Flattens a single list-like table. Errors if it attempts to flatten a
--- dict-like table
---@param v table table which should be flattened
---@param max_depth number depth to which the table should be flattened
---@param depth number current iteration depth
---@param result table output table that contains flattened result
---@return table flattened table if it can be flattened, otherwise nil
local function flatten(v, max_depth, depth, result)

comment_data.body:
I added tests for `depth = 0` and verified they return the same thing. sorry for accepting the suggestions - I usually just click that to close them all then do a fixup later üòÖ 

to your second question -- right now, passing a negative is equivalent to passing 0. I added a test to illustrate this behavior. I can make it error if that is preferred.
Throwing errors would be better for invalid parameters, but I don't have a strong opinion. Maybe we can just leave the behavior undocumented and undefined. @justinmk may have a better opinion here.

comment_regular_data.body: news.txt already includes an entry on `vim.iter`, so I don't think I am going to update that for this

I would suggest we add *comprehensive* tests on various corner cases about the behavior (and document them well), even when a NOT-list-like table is given, or a table contains `nil`, etc.:

```lua
> vim.tbl_flatten({1, {2, 3, nil, 4}, 5, {6, a = 7, b = 8}})
< { 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6 }

> vim.iter.flat({1, {2, 3, nil, 4}, 5, {6, a = 7, b = 8}})
< { 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 8, 7 }
```

> I would suggest we add _comprehensive_ tests on various corner cases about the behavior (and document them well), even when a NOT-list-like table is given, or a table contains `nil`, etc.:
> 
> ```lua
> > vim.tbl_flatten({1, {2, 3, nil, 4}, 5, {6, a = 7, b = 8}})
> < { 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6 }
> 
> > vim.iter.flat({1, {2, 3, nil, 4}, 5, {6, a = 7, b = 8}})
> < { 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 8, 7 }
> ```



that's a great call ! I tested when the first level was not a list-like table, but not the inner-levels ü§í . This is also potentially a bug with `Iter:new()` since it doesn't check deeper than one level in validating when validating that an iterator is list-like https://github.com/rudiejd/neovim/blob/3de60f4c9c68a9571d292e0e495a7a30ee071849/runtime/lua/vim/iter.lua#L1007-L1017

is the desired behavior here to ignore key-like values and nil a-la `vim.tbl_flatten`, or to include them in the same order? I'm just going to go with ignoring them for now for consistency and document this as such, but it's an interesting question.

I think there are still issues in dealing with non-list table. What is our decision when it comes to a non-list (dict) table that are nested? Either non-error or eager error checking is fine, but consistency would be better.

```
> vim.iter({ a = 3 }) :flatten(math.huge):totable()
< Error: flatten() requires a list-like table

> vim.iter({1, { a = 3 }}) :flatten(math.huge):totable()
< {1}
```

> I think there are still issues in dealing with non-list table. What is our decision when it comes to a non-list (dict) table that are nested? Either non-error or eager error checking is fine, but consistency would be better.
> 
> ```
> > vim.iter({ a = 3 }) :flatten(math.huge):totable()
> < Error: flatten() requires a list-like table
> 
> > vim.iter({1, { a = 3 }}) :flatten(math.huge):totable()
> < {1}
> ```

That's a good point on the inconsistency. Seems related to @justinmk's comment too. I only required being list-like at the top level, but then wiped out nested tables that weren't list-like. 

I think a non-error as fine *as long as* the non-list like table is not being flattened.

Proposal:
- for each value,
    - if it's a list, flatten it
    - if it's a dict, don't recurse into it (don't flatten it)
        - thus if the top-level value is dict-like, it just returns the dict.
- to decide if a value is list-like:
    - use the same logic as `vim.iter`: https://github.com/neovim/neovim/blob/031088fc0afffe4af6fa90d68d5b93ca09992ef1/runtime/lua/vim/iter.lua#L954
    - for efficiency, build the flattened list _while also_ iterating to check if it is a list.
        - return early if any key is found that indicates the container is dict-like.
    - related: https://github.com/neovim/neovim/issues/24746
- document this behavior in the docstring.

This should be done, let me know what you think :) 

> Proposal:
>       * if it's a dict, don't recurse into it (don't flatten it)

I ended up erroring instead of not flattening, since as @wookayin mentioned it seems inconsistent to error on top-level dict-like members, but not nested ones. on an error, the function will return the source iterator without modifications.
